results.justification: The paper explicitly states the research focuses on detecting collusion in online assessments using feature engineering and machine learning. (e.g., "We used feature engineering and ML algorithms to create a model for the detection of collusion.")
Sections 3.1, 3.2, and 3.3 provide a detailed step-by-step description of the study design, including dataset creation, feature engineering, and the ML model building process.

The paper states: "To enhance the usability and reproducibility of our work, we have open-sourced the iQuiz tool and made the collected data publicly available." and provides a DOI: https://doi.org/10.6084/m9.figshare.23744283.v1
Section 3.1 describes the dataset, including variables like 'Student', 'Question', 'Response', 'Score', 'Start', 'Revisions', and 'Time'. Figure 1 provides a sample dataset.
Section 3.1 details the data collection process, including the use of iQuiz, the setting (university lecture hall), and the type of assessment (MCQs).
The paper states: "we have open-sourced the iQuiz tool..."
The paper mentions feature engineering and the use of scikit-learn, implying code was used for data preparation, and the iQuiz tool is open-sourced.
The paper clearly describes the statistical tests and models used, including Logistic Regression, SVM, Decision Trees, XGBoost, and Random Forest. (Section 3.3)
The paper reports accuracy, precision, recall, and F1-score for each classifier (Section 4.1.1).
The study is primarily quantitative; subjective context and interpretation are limited.
N/A - No qualitative data analysis is performed.
Results are presented in figures (e.g., Fig. 3, Fig. 4, Fig. 5, Fig. 6, Fig. 7) and tables (Table 4), with clear descriptions.
Section 4.3 discusses limitations, including the use of experimental datasets and the potential for coincidental observations.
The paper does not contain a link to a preregistration.
